docs.lead_paragraph: Hospitals and insurance companies can readily obtain information about a physician's malpractice claims, but in most states the public cannot. But in at least 15 states, the Federation of State Medical Boards says, some such records are available on official Web sites. Physician groups in most states oppose the practice. Gale Scott discussed the issue with the presidents of two medical societies. These are edited excerpts of those interviews. YES. The Massachusetts Board of Registration in Medicine began its Physician Profiles Project in 1996. The project has resulted in a Web site where visitors can get information about paid malpractice claims along with a physician's business and professional demographics, education and training, hospital affiliations and the insurance plans accepted. If the doctor has had disciplinary actions or a criminal history that will also be online.

headline.main: The Place for Public Documents: On File or Online?

docs.abstract: Excerpts from interviews with Massachusetts Medical Society president Francis X Rockett and Illinois State Medical Society president Ronald L Rucker, in which they take opposing views on whether information about malpractice claims against physicians should be made available on the Internet; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Hospitals and insurance companies can readily obtain information about a physician's malpractice claims, but in most states the public cannot. But in at least 15 states, the Federation of State Medical Boards says, some such records are available on...

docs.lead_paragraph: Nine days after signing the second tax cut since he took office, President Bush today proposed a new round of cuts, intended largely for small businesses, a constituency he is heavily courting for the coming Congressional elections. Speaking at a small manufacturing company here on his way to a fund-raiser for a Republican seeking a critical seat in the Senate, Mr. Bush revived a plan that would increase the amount small businesses can deduct immediately for the purchase of equipment. The proposal would cost about $7 billion over 10 years, the White House said, a relatively small amount compared with other tax cuts. But to the dismay of small-business owners and workers, it was dropped at the last minute from the economic stimulus package that Congress passed this month.

headline.main: Bush Revives Tax-Cut Plan Providing Aid To Businesses

docs.abstract: Pres Bush proposes new round of tax cuts aimed largely at small businesses, constituency he is heavily courting for Congressional elections, nine days after signing second tax cut since taking office; revives plan, during visit to O'Fallon, Mo, that would increase amount small business can deduct immediately for purchase of equipment, which was dropped at last minute from economic stimulus package Congress passed earlier in month; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Nine days after signing the second tax cut since he took office, President Bush today proposed a new round of cuts, intended largely for small businesses, a constituency he is heavily courting for the coming Congressional elections.    Speaking at a...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Many Doctors Shun Patients With Medicare'' (front page, March 17):
docs.abstract: Dr James A Slater letter on March 17 article scores Bush administration's proposed cut in Medicare payments
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Re ''Many Doctors Shun Patients With Medicare'' (front page, March 17):

docs.lead_paragraph: Sunday's front-page article in The Times on doctors who shun patients with Medicare may have been alarming enough; it seems that recent cuts in Medicare payments are inducing many doctors to avoid treating Medicare recipients at all. But this is just the beginning of a struggle that will soon dominate American politics. Think of it as the collision between an irresistible force (the growing cost of health care) and an immovable object (the determination of America's conservative movement to downsize government). For the moment the Bush administration and its allies still won't admit that there is any conflict between their promises to retirees and their small-government ideology. But we're already past the stage where this conflict can be hidden with fudged numbers. The effort to live within unrealistically low targets for Medicare expenses has already translated into unrealistically low payments to health-care providers. And it gets worse from here.
docs.abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column foresees collision between growing cost of health care and determination of America's conservative movement to downsize government; says effort to live within unrealistically low targets for Medicare expenses has already translated into unrealistically low payments to health-care providers, some of whom now say they will avoid treating Medicare recipients at all; says Bush administration is still trying to fake it, with budget proposal that assumes far lower rate of growth in Medicare expenses than anyone else thinks plausible; holds that it must come up with more money or deny health care to retirees (M)
docs.snippet: Sunday's front-page article in The Times on doctors who shun patients with Medicare may have been alarming enough; it seems that recent cuts in Medicare payments are inducing many doctors to avoid treating Medicare recipients at all.  But this is...

docs.lead_paragraph: Managed care plans in California will be required to refer H.I.V. patients to doctors certified as AIDS specialists under regulations scheduled to take effect in July, making the state the first to impose such a requirement on private health insurers. Studies have shown that H.I.V. patients fare best when treated by doctors who have experience with the virus. But there is no broadly accepted definition of what constitutes expertise in H.I.V., so health plans have generally been left to devise their own standards, which vary widely.

headline.main: California Is Tightening Rules on H.I.V. Care

docs.abstract: California, first state to impose such regulations, will require managed care plans, beginning in July, to refer HIV patients to doctors certified as AIDS specialists; AIDS advocates applaud new rules and expect them to influence debate in other states; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Not only are doctors refusing to treat new Medicare patients (front page, March 17), but in Manhattan they are limiting the kinds of patients they will see as well. Last year I was referred to an internist by another doctor. The internist told me that he didn't accept Medicare, that an office visit cost $400 and that I could then seek reimbursement from Medicare. Medicare reimburses $40 for a visit. JEROME BROOKS New York, March 17, 2002
docs.abstract: Jerome Brooks letter shares personal experience relative to March 17 article on Bush administration plan to cut Medicare payments to health care providers

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 Israeli Forces Withdraw In Move Toward Cease-Fire Israeli ground forces began withdrawing early from Palestinian-controlled territory in Bethlehem and two other West Bank towns, the Israeli Army said, as Israel moved under American pressure toward meeting Palestinian conditions for formal cease-fire talks. The pullback came as Vice President Dick Cheney arrived in Jerusalem for meetings with Israeli officials. A1 Worker Protests in China Public protests by workers displaced by the overhaul of state industries are becoming larger and angrier, with huge demonstrations breaking out in several places this month. And if the recent reports are any guide, the scale of the unrest is likely to grow as China opens more industries to competition under World Trade Organization rules. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: TO the dismay of some doctors and a few big drug companies, Dr. Robert C. Seidman may soon be able to say he helped save the health care system hundreds of millions of dollars. Four years ago, Dr. Seidman, the chief pharmacy officer at Wellpoint Health Systems, the large California health insurer, filed a petition with the Food and Drug Administration asking that Claritin, the blockbuster allergy medicine, and its two competitors, Allegra and Zyrtec, be sold without a prescription.

headline.main: A Drug Will Cost Less. For Whom?

docs.abstract: Melody Petersen column says health insurers stand to benefit more than patients when prescription drugs are made available over the counter, as should happen this year with allergy medication Claritin; also notes possibility that without having to see doctor for prescription, patients will be free to self-medicate and this may allow more serious conditions to go undiagnosed; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: MUTUAL fund companies, big brokerage firms and the financial advisers who rely on their data work very hard to convince future retirees that they will need 70 to 80 percent of their preretirement income to live comfortably once they quit working. Other advisers contend that these estimates are self-serving, intended to attract customers and their money. They say that if your home is paid for, you need much less to retire than you might have been led to believe -- especially if you are willing to move to a less expensive part of the country. These advisers say you should weigh expenses, not income, when calculating needs. They see 40 to 60 percent of preretirement income as more accurately in line with postretirement expenses.

headline.main: Personal Business; How Much Will You Need to Retire? It Helps to Plan

docs.abstract: Fred Brock column on planning for retirement and calculating how much income you will need to do it; recommends three recent books: Retire in Style by Warren R Bland, The Complete Idiot's Guide to Retiring Early by Dee Lee and Jim Flewelling and Retirement on a Shoestring by John Howells (M)
